all right sir hi everyone I'm Chris and I want to talk to you
about happiness because happy developers
are better developers right if you're feeling stressed or maybe upset over
something it's only naturally going to be harder for you to do your best work and of course happiness for you could be
about any number of things it could be about having a really supportive team at work it could be about having realistic
goals and deadlines that don't put you under too much pressure it could be about having all sorts of different
learning opportunities to help you grow in your professional career all honestly
any number of other things that are important to you there are so many different factors that have such a big
impact on how happy we are but today I'm not actually here to talk about the big
things instead for my time here today I'd like us to focus on the little
things which can still have a big impact for an example how about your keyboard
now a keyboard alone probably won't turn you into this disconcertingly excited
office worker but it could make more of a difference
than you'd think bear with me for a little while and I'll tell you how I
improved as a developer when I started caring more about my keyboard so for a
long time I use just a bog-standard keyboard like everyone else I'm sure we've all used a keyboard like this at
some point but one of my co-workers at a previous job they had a mechanical
keyboard now in case you're not familiar with mechanical keyboards the idea with
these is they're functionally the same as any regular keyboard but every single key has a distinct physical switch
inside it that you have to press down in order to activate the key you might also
know these as the keyboards that make they're really loud like clicky clicky sounds from over the other side of the
office now my coworker at my last job
they really loved their keyboard and they used it all the time but for a long
time I wasn't convinced I just thought that keyboards a keyboard right like how
much of a difference can it actually make but fast-forward a little bit later
and I got myself a new job and I got my first new job paycheck so I thought okay
this is the best time to like go and buy myself something that I wouldn't normally buy and the more that I thought
about it the more I thought why not get myself a new keyboard it's something that I'll be using every day so it's a
good investment and I can just see what this Fosse's or has been about all this time so I went out and I bought myself
this keyboard it's a it's a ducky zero which is in fact the same keyboard that
my coworker had at the previous job and you know sure it's it was the same as
any other keyboard but as I got used to it I found you know it did make my everyday typing experience just that
little bit nicer and you know I got quite attached to it over time so you
know I was quite happy with this and I figured what what more could I possibly need until I made the mistake of going
on Reddit so if you're not familiar with some of
the communities on reddit there's mechanical keyboards community where people show off photos of keyboards that
they've bought or sometimes even built themselves by getting the components and building it from scratch and honestly
the stuff that I saw here kind of blew my mind a bit I was seeing things like you know these really cool compact
keyboards that you know had a bit of a smaller form factor and saved on space or I saw these weird things called Auto
linear keyboards where everything's arranged in a grid or keyboards that were split into two distinct halves and
the more that I looked into it the more I realized that this wasn't just about showing off or having something that
looked really cool people had all sorts of reasons for building or buying keyboards like these the most common one
was typically that you can customize the layout of it to be like anything you want so if you have I don't know certain
shortcuts that you use a lot in different software you can make them easier to use on your custom layout
another big one is ergonomic s-- such as the split keyboards that we just saw they let you keep your hands in a more
natural resting position rather than having to kind of force them in to use a keyboard which helps you know prevent
RSI and stuff some people would maximize portability so they'd go for something as small as
they could reasonably manage so that they could take it to and from work without a taking up too much space in
their bag and after a while looking at these you know I got to be honest I
started getting a bit of keyboard Envy so I wanted to find a way to try and
jazz out my keyboard a little bit and so I went and bought a set of custom key
caps for my existing keyboard it's just the same keyboard that with a new set of
key caps that you replace and pull the old ones off and stick these ones on and honestly I was more excited than I care
to admit when these came in because it was just like all of a sudden I had you
know it was the same old keyboard but it just looked really fresh and you people would walk past and say hey
it's a nice looking keyboard and I'd walk in in the morning and look at it and think and this is just really nice
it kind of goes a little bit beyond that over time a few more interesting things started to happen so because I was
enjoying using my keyboard so much it made me want to find excuses to use it
more so I spent some more time starting to learn the keyboard shortcuts for all
the various programs that I use I started spending more time trying to learn how to use the command line
properly just because it let me use the keyboard more and you know over time I
found that I did get you know a bit more productive or a bit more efficient at certain things just because you know I
wanted to use it as much as I could and then a little bit later on when I wanted
to go to the next level and build my own keyboard which I do actually have here
by the way I was able to you know like I said take it to that next level and try
and create a layout that would suit me the way that I wanted and got to learn a few things about electronics and
soldiering along the way but that's enough about me I only have so much time
here so let's get to the really important points here this talk is not about making you write out to buy an
expensive keyboard although I hope you find my story interesting maybe you don't care at all about keyboards and
that's totally fine rather I think the thing that made a big difference to me
is that you know getting a nice keyboard just took a really common part of my
workday typing and it just injected a bit of fun into it over time that kind
of gave me something to look forward to or get a bit excited about and bit by bit that helped me get better as a
developer so I'd like to put this to you what gets you excited for work
maybe it's as simple as just finding the perfect playlist that puts you in the
coding mood maybe it's about picking that perfect color scheme for your favorite text editor or maybe it's about
decorating your workspace with nice pieces of art that you just really like sitting by these things might seem a

you know no matter how good it is they'll never be able to make you 100% happy so I think anything that you can
do to get yourself excited for work and to make it a better place for you helps pave the way for you to be a
happier and better developer thank you
